2025-05-03 20:30:33,251 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the country’s top import, electronic products, surged declined slightly year-on-year to 8.2 percent in april 2006.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses trade data, specifically imports, without mentioning any monetary policy implications or decisions."

\\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on 16 september 2022, the land transportation franchising and regulatory board (ltfrb) decided to collectively raise transport fares across several public transport vehicles.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:30:36,939 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The decision to raise transport fares may lead to higher costs for consumers, which could negatively impact the economy, thus signaling a need for monetary easing."
}

indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: results of the consensus economics survey for march 2017 showed higher mean inflation forecasts for 2017 at 3.2 percent (from 3.1 percent in the previous month) while mean inflation forecast for 2018 was steady at 3.3 percent.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "Higher mean inflation forecasts for 2017 indicate a potential need for contractionary monetary policy to control inflation."
}

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - at the same time, catch-up fiscal spending is expected to help sustain the growth momentum in the remainder of 2019.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: majority of the members of the monetary board also noted that the current interest rate differentials remained comfortable, suggesting a case for further monetary easing without raising concerns on a possible adverse impact in the foreign exchange market.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:30:46,127 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests a case for further monetary easing, indicating a dovish stance."
}

for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - for the first week of december 2020, the peso appreciated against the us dollar amid market optimism over news of progress in the development of a vaccine against covid-19 as well as the release of lower-than-expected philippine unemployment data for october 2020.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The peso's appreciation and lower-than-expected unemployment data indicate a positive economic outlook, which may lead to a dovish monetary policy stance."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: commercial bank lending grew by 3.8 percent in august, a slight improvement from the 3.7 percent annual rise in the previous month.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports a slight improvement in commercial bank lending, but does not indicate a significant change in monetary policy or a clear direction for interest rates."
}

\\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: such a prospect increases not Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this represented 41.5 percent of the p279.1 billion programmed deficit for q1-q4 2012.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only provides a percentage of a programmed deficit without mentioning any monetary policy decision or stance."
}

November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: "justification": "The increase in net foreign assets and liquidity expansion suggests a higher money supply, which is a dovish signal."
}

2025-05-03 20:31:12,910 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - domestic labor market conditions continued to show overall improvement.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:31:12,910 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates an improvement in labor market conditions, which may lead to a decrease in unemployment and a need for monetary easing to stimulate the economy."
}

accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, the volume of production index (vopi) declined by 5.0 percent in september, a reversal from the 5.0 percent expansion in august.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:31:16,935 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "A decline in the volume of production index suggests a slowdown in economic activity, which may warrant monetary easing to stimulate growth."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the next meeting of the monetary board on monetary policy issues is scheduled on 28 january 2010.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for the period january-june 2002, the da has forecasted palay and corn production at 5.72 million metric tons and 2.05 million metric tons, respectively, up by 2.7 percent and 4.7 percent from the previous year’s level.\n                "}]

Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: to cushion the impact of these challenges on the country’s food security, the national government has implemented crucial non-monetary measures to fill supply gaps and boost local production, such as rice imports to augment supply in the domestic market, the extension of lower tariff rates on pork imports, and the relaxation of quantitative import restrictions for sugar processors over the near-term, among others.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses non-monetary measures implemented by the national government to address food security, with no mention of monetary policy or interest rates."
}

levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the monetary board decided to: a) maintain the overnight rrp (borrowing) rate at 3.0 percent; and b) maintain the current overnight deposit and overnight lending rates.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide}
